title: Failed Certificate Validation On Custom Server (Register)

profile.name: RelateIQ
profile.about: Goodbye, Relationship Management. Hello, Relationship Intelligence.

vulnerability_information:
Hi,

in the register page a custom server can be used to define "where to connect to". Your system does not validate the SSL certificate of this host which makes it easy to tamper with the data your system do in behalf of the user.

As only SSL links are allowed by the application the user could assume that the implementation is according to security best practice and would validate the certificate trustchain on connect. Additional "relateiq" might can guarantee the security of any connection under control, but the connection made over insecure networks could be tampered by anyone with access to this system.

I have used ncat which generates a certificate on the fly to demonstrate the issue:

ncat --ssl -p 443 -v -n -l
Ncat: Version 6.46 ( http://nmap.org/ncat )
Ncat: Generating a temporary 1024-bit RSA key. Use --ssl-key and --ssl-cert to use a permanent one.

activities.message:
Hi John,

in this scenario your system (aka "RelateIQ system") initiates a connection to "my server" via a secure connection (SSL). In that scenario your system (at RelateIQ) is the client and I am hosting the server, therefore the client (your system) needs to validate the server (my system) certificate. However, a connection is performed from the "RelateIQ system" even if an "untrusted" certificate is present on my system.

My recommendation is to validate the certificate against the operating system default builtin storage of CA certs and if the certificate cannot be validated as "trusted", do not perform the handshake ...

Sorry if my initial submission wasn't clear enough. Please let me know if that clarifies your questions.

Thanks

pUm

activities.message:
Hi Pum. To explain it a little more. Your client hits our CDN, our CDN has a wildcard certificate that hosts multiple domains on their cert, then the CDN caches and proxies to our load balancer with our own certificate. What you're seeing is the connection to the CDN. Now we can't fix our CDN at the moment unless we move off of them nor change their certificate. 

If you change your hosts file name for app.relateiq.com to elb-app-prod-vpc-public3-1178699437.us-west-2.elb.amazonaws.com do you still get the issue? This is our direct load balancer taking the CDN out of the loop. 

If you can confirm the issue exists there as well then we can invesitgate further however I don't believe this is an issue at the moment.

activities.message:
Hi John,

I am sorry to say, but the issue you describe has nothing to do with the vuln I have found. What yo describe would still mean that *I* initiate a connection to your server. However, the feature I am discussing here is that YOU (your server, loadbalancer, whatever) is initiating a connection to the outside world. With initiating the connection I speak of TCP a SYN. As you can see in my first posting the IP 54.218.20.199 (relate to Amazon) connects from a high (client) TCP port to a low TCP port (443) on my server.

To maybe start from the very beginning ... when you register an account with your system - you can chose to use an exchange account (office365). Within that setting you can say "show advance options". In this option you can define to which exchange a connection should be made (please see the screenshot in the first post too). The connection which is made at THAT point does not validate the certificate.

I have really no idea how other/better I could explain the issue. However, I believe it is a very serious issue, because the SSL connection could be tampered without your system realizing it putting all client data (including domain passwords) at risk which uses custom connections ... therefore, in case you do not understand (no offense please, it is probably my reporting style ...)  what I've found here, maybe another colleague from you could cross check and re-read the issue? 

Thanks

pUm

activities.message:
Hi John,

again - this has nothing to do with any certificate under your control. This is purely about certificate validation which is required to be performed by the relateIQ system which acts as a client in the scenario described above, because a user can define a custom server to connect and authenticate to.

My recommendation is still to get a third person involved to clarify this issue. Otherwise we can close the issue and make it public if you believe it is not an issue - but there is not much else I can write unless the issue is acknowledged and understood. 

Thanks

pUm
